Sitting with my 6 year old son in the fourth row in the bright sunshine behind the visitors dugout, Royals Stadium, May, 1997. This intense kid with big ears comes up and hits a rocket into the fountain in right center, a meaningless run in the requisite Yankees' shellacking of the KC nine. Yet still the respectful and baseball savvy and somewhat thinned out KC crowd let out a collective, awestruck "oooohhhh" on contact. Turned to my son and said, he'll remember that home run the rest of his life. Why? my boy took the bait. That's his first major league home run. How many's he gonna hit? my boy asks naively, with that beautiful optimism that boys bring to this beautiful game. I couldn't help feed his belief... based on the noise his bat made hitting the ball, he's gonna hit a bunch.
Little did we know, with all those championships and clutch hits and heads up plays and intense consultations on the mound, and, yes, home runs, that we would forget our early struggles pronouncing his name, and will never forget his impact on the team the game, and on my now 21 year-old son, and his pop, as Jorge Posada will endure in our hearts and minds for as long as we have memory.
Thanks Jorge for playing for my Yankees. Character, drive, intensity, passion and talent, your legacy is set in stone, you've notched your name on the wall with the greats. Thank you.

The graph, showing public sector cuts slowing recovery, is a good argument for what we had in the 1970s, "counter-cyclical revenue sharing." The federal government increased aid, with few strings attached, to state and local governments when economic growth was slow or non-existent, so states & localities could continue to provide essential services and not be a drag on the economy. By the late 1970s it was better targeted so it could serve the most good and be used where it was most needed. Then Reagan took office and ended it.

I'm surprised, given the state and local government drag on our economy in recent years, that I have not seen or heard any calls to revive counter-cyclical revenue sharing. Maybe because it was started by that radical left-wing communist, Richard Nixon.

"Fannie and Freddie" sound like an irresponsible couple who win the lottery and blow the money at the tables. They're just a ® strawman for the real culprits: the few who, positioned to accomplish the task and morally unopposed to any means to achieve it, wanted a bigger piece of the United States Financial Pot.

They placed big bets, even against themselves, to sweeten the pot. Sold pieces of the bets to pension funds, nonprofits, governments, anyone who trusted their good names, and manipulated Congresses over decades, deregulating this and that and "trusting the market" to self-oversight. All - as far as I've read - legal. And then they lost. The world Financial Market called their bluff.

They certainly don't expect their own world to come crashing down; like Mr. Madoff, they figured they'll be long gone by the time it's sorted out… there will be fingers pointing in so many directions, with people chasing down blind alleys and fluffing strawmen whenever the truth gets too close… they'll escape unscathed.

Besides, George Bush bailed them out, as buddies do in a jam. And the claim they were "too big to fail" must've been true, since they would be devastated if they did. They had a lot of friends in that Congress.

If Fannie and Freddie had a fatal flaw, it's that they believed the advice someone was giving them. Could that have been part of the "historical analysis" Mr. Gingrich provided? Perhaps he riffed on the cultural touchstone of Gordon Gekko: "Greed... is good."

Why do so many people believe that mothers must justify their choice to parent children--and avoid inconveniencing anyone else?  By carrying and birthing children, and engaging in activities that contribute to their children's well-being, like breastfeeding, mothers are performing a unique service to society.  Breastfeeding can help to improve the baby and mother's health, cutting health care costs for employers.  Instead of punishing mothers, employers should encourage breastfeeding.  Mothers shouldn't be discriminated against or shamed for selfless behavior that benefits everyone.

When one stops screaming about the drain on our American way of life caused by state union employees, and the federal government bureaucracy, one might then consider that all those workers also happen to turn their government paychecks into consumer spending. But that would point out the fact government employees actually contribute to the economy in positive ways. And that would really ruin the Bogeyman Government narrative.
